channel.title: Final and static
channel.description: Someone told me that using final static ints improve performance, I don't believe this is true... But.. Is it? ^__^

item.title: Final and static
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

Often, a VM may use the fact that a variable ‘final’ as a hint that may assist in JIT optimizations, e.g. inlining and folding.

Read full topic

item.title: Final and static
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

the final keyword is the same as the const keyword when applied to a pointer in C/C++ - this means that the reference to the object cannot be changed, but the object itself can be if it is mutable. The aforementioned does not apply to primitives though… a final primitive is the same a constant in C++ (completely immutable). finalized members must be assigned a value either on a static constructor or constructor.

the static keyword tells the JVM (or OS in C/C++) where to allocate the memory with in virtual memory. static members are declared only once whereas non-static members are re-declared for every instance of a module/class. the advantage of this is that the module/class can maintain state.

edit: as for performance goes, static members will utilize less memory since they’re not re-allocated every time an object is constructed. the final/cost modifier doesn’t effect performance, it is used to manage how the variable is used by the programmer.

Read full topic

item.title: Final and static
item.dc:creator: @xxxtilllyxxx xxxtilllyxxx
item.description:
@xxxtilllyxxx wrote:

For once I am considered correct. What has this world come to??? I think it’s the apocalypse.

Read full topic

item.title: Final and static
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

Static variables are bound to the class, so they’re created once and use only one spot in memory. For universal constants such as PI, that’s perfect.

Read full topic

item.title: Final and static
item.dc:creator: @ravekitty ravekitty
item.description:
@ravekitty wrote:

xxxtilllyxxx:

No, they are just modifiers. Final means the JVM can not change the value of a primitive. And static means that only one instance of a static field exists even if you create a million instances of the class or you don’t create any. It will be shared by all instances.

Oh ok. Thanks ;d

Read full topic
